overview: This measure now includes a significant, one-time appropriation for infrastructure projects, expanding the bill's scope beyond solely financing accessory dwelling units. The program's sunset date is clarified to be January 1, 2031. The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation is tasked with expending these new infrastructure funds.
appropriations: A new, one-time appropriation of $20,000,000 from the general revenues of the State is established for fiscal year 2025-2026. These funds are to be deposited into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. Subsequently, the measure appropriates $20,000,000 from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for infrastructure projects.
assumptions_and_methodology: The Department of Taxation has provided specific revenue loss projections related to the conveyance tax exemption created by the measure. The estimated impact on the General Fund is a loss of $0.9 million in FY 2026, increasing annually to $2.3 million in FY 2031. These calculations are based on the number of properties expected to participate in the program and receive the tax exemption.
agency_impact: In addition to administering the Accessory Dwelling Unit program, the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation is now responsible for expending a new $20,000,000 appropriation designated for infrastructure projects. The Department of Taxation will be required to administer the new conveyance tax exemption, which takes effect on January 1, 2026. This will result in a measurable reduction in General Fund revenues.
economic_impact: The measure will result in a direct negative impact on General Fund revenues due to the conveyance tax exemption for participating properties. The Department of Taxation estimates this revenue loss will begin at $0.9 million in fiscal year 2026. The loss is projected to increase to $1.9 million in FY 2027, $2.0 million in FY 2028, $2.1 million in FY 2029, $2.2 million in FY 2030, and $2.3 million in FY 2031.
revenue_sources: The measure now designates general fund revenues as the source for a new, one-time $20,000,000 appropriation in fiscal year 2025-2026. These funds will be channeled through the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund specifically for infrastructure projects. This is in addition to the previously identified Rental Housing Revolving Fund for the ADU equity purchase program.
six_year_fiscal_implications: The six-year outlook now includes a one-time appropriation of $20,000,000 from the General Fund in fiscal year 2025-2026 for infrastructure projects, to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. In parallel, the measure will create a recurring revenue loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption. According to the Department of Taxation, this loss is projected to be $0.9 million in FY 2026, $1.9 million in FY 2027, $2.0 million in FY 2028, $2.1 million in FY 2029, $2.2 million in FY 2030, and $2.3 million in FY 2031. These figures are in addition to the previously established $2,000,000 annual cap on allocations from the Rental Housing Revolving Fund for the ADU program itself.
operating_revenue_impact: The conveyance tax exemption is now quantified with specific negative revenue impact projections from the Department of Taxation. The estimated reduction in General Fund revenues is $0.9 million in FY 2026, rising annually to $2.3 million by FY 2031. This provides a precise forecast of the operating revenue loss associated with the program.
capital_expenditure_impact: A new capital expenditure of $20,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2025-2026. These funds originate from general revenues and are directed through the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation is tasked with expending this amount specifically for infrastructure projects.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The projected revenue loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption is now expected to continue beyond the six-year outlook. The Department of Taxation estimates a revenue loss of $2.3 million for fiscal year 2031, which occurs after the program sunsets. This indicates an ongoing, though non-compounding, fiscal impact from properties that participated in the program.
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The most significant update is the addition of a new, one-time $20,000,000 appropriation from the General Fund for infrastructure projects in fiscal year 2025-2026. This expands the bill's fiscal scope beyond the ADU equity purchase program. Additionally, the fiscal impact of the conveyance tax exemption has been specifically quantified by the Department of Taxation, projecting an annual revenue loss to the General Fund from FY 2026 through FY 2031.
